The primary reason Asia supports our (US) debt is to maintain and advance their industrial technology and production capability. EU, to a much lesser extent, also has the same dependency. That's a major reason that while we looked stupid for invading Iraq, little was said or done by our trading partners. All trading countries want the US to economically keep our heads above water, even if it takes additional, unreasonable debt and limited war to drive our GDP and retain consumer confidence. The goal is expanded Asian markets, China in particular, to replace US volume. 
 
 In 2004 the US CIA estimated China's GDP at $7.2trillion USD, based on exchange rates with the supposedly undervalued Yuan (RMB). The US, at $11.7trillion GDP, is currently at around a 3% annual GDP growth rate. China's annual growth rate is 10% (supposedly reduced to 9%). With continued growth, China will be where we are now in five years, probably less. And that's with a positive payment balance, industrial economy. 
 
 No one wants the US to fail, at least not right now. Our GDP is full of holes from debt not calculated into GDP numbers and the fact we're now primarily a internal transaction economy, feeding on ourselves. Ideally we can keep all the balls in the air for another ten-years, when China would numerically surpass our GDP, but that'll be quite a feat on our present course. If we can keep going at our present rate for another five years, Asia and the EU would not founder with us as even if we lost 20% of our GDP due to economic circumstances as expanded internal Asian markets would take up most of the slack. Simplified, but the basics are all that's required.
